reviews.title: Not a family park
text: Disgusting place. Always has been and always will be.  No place to take children or even a dog.
It should have been closed down years ago.

reviews.title: Beware of syringes
text: I live by this park. Great children's playground and splash pad.  However, yesterday multiple heroin needles were found in the sand where children play. Today, a drug vile was found in a high-traffic area by the splash pad. More and more tents are popping up close to the children's play areas. If you have children, make sure to inspect the sand and grass for needles. It's a shame that kids can't be care-free in city parks.

reviews.title: Great green space at trendy area
text: Beautiful, small park (approx 300 m X 300 m), with kids'area (splash pad, playground), recreation center (gym, pool, etc), tennis courts, off leash dog area, forested and open areas. We used to run, relax, picnic at this park - Highly recommended, especially for lazy Sunday afternoons in the summer. Not much to do in the winter, except walking your pets.

reviews.title: Accessible for treehuggers with limited mobility
text: Bracketed between streetcar lines, you don't have to venture far into the park (especially from the north) before finding a really nice tree to spend some time with. You'll find picnickers, dog walkers, hippies, and people just enjoying the day. Not as sprawling as High Park and but with a greater green canopy of many other smaller parks, this is perfectly accessible for those who can't or don't want to walk far. And if you do? It's a nice stroll end to end. In the north west corner you'll find a bemused looking bronze bust depicting the Liberator, Simón Bolívar. The image of the Venezuelan hero appears surprised to be in a Canadian park.

reviews.title: Nice
text: Nice park with lots of sitting options. When I was there it was kind of wet and muddy but it was just the time of the year. Lots of young people hanging around so that’s nice.

reviews.title: Cherry Blossoms
text: We stumbled across this huge and lovely park when strolling along Queen Street West. The park was full of people taking pictures of the beautiful cherry blossom trees, having picnics and playing games. Lots of dogs were out enjoying the spring day. Lovely.

reviews.title: Every time is a wonderful time.
text: While this park does not have a restaurant IN the park, there are countless options on either side of the park to grab a coffee or a fabulous meal. The park itself is an oasis right in the heart of the city. Many facilities. Beautiful paths. Always lots going on!

reviews.title: Beautiful
text: The park is huge. Lots of benches surrounded by trees space to lay out your blanket and chill have a picnic or suntan.
Area for dogs lots of people bike riding ...
A gem in the city

reviews.title: Calm and peaceful
text: Walk around the city brought me to this park. Very calm and peaceful this day I was in it. Walked around. Saw there were placed for unleashed dogs. Places for kids playing. Places for picnic.
Beautiful coloured trees now during the autumn.
Nice place to chill for a while.

reviews.title: Nice area for picnic
text: This is a nice area for picnic, a place where you can go with the family and spend an entire afternoon.

reviews.title: A fun quirky place to visit!
text: I lived right by Trinity Bellwoods Park for a few years and loved how much happens here. One day it could be just walking the dog in the park, the next there was a food event, the weekend after was an arts fair etc always something going on. Lovely place to visit and the shops near by are great.

reviews.title: Peaceful and in the middle of everything
text: This park is an alternative in west TO to highpark. Smaller and less busy than highpark but more romantic and ideal for a lunch in middle of fall or summer. The southern part of the park is more beautiful than the north part.
Have fun and bring your dog

reviews.title: You'll Wanna Move here
text: Where do I start? First off I got an airbnb apartment in this amazing neighborhood. My purpose for the trip was to go to the OVO fest concert that Drake throws every year. It also happened to be Caribana which is an amazing Caribbean festival that occurs every year. Toronto has a very eclectic mix of ethnicity. Unlike the U.S., people actually get a long up here. The most cleanest city I have seen since Chicago. A very walkable city and public transportation is simply amazing. Canadians are amongst the most kindest people I have ever encountered and the culture seems to embrace that kindness. My suggestion would be to get the CITYpass because you will save slot of money doing so and arrive to places early. use the cabs as they are pretty cheap in comparison to a bigger city. The Food here is amazing. I am very fond of a 24 hour diner called The Thompson. Very upscale and the food is AMAZING ! Go to Kensington Markets ! King and Queens street have amazing bars and clubs

reviews.title: Great community park, perfect for walking your dog or simply relaxing
text: This park is located in a residential area of Toronto, perfect for relaxing, people watching and a great spot to walk your pooch as well. Depending on the day, there are often, local artist, vendors and promotions around the park. If in the surrounding area and in need for a ray of sun and a relaxing spot to hang, this is the place to check out. Simply pack your own picnic, or try a local restaurant or food truck in the area!

reviews.title: Great way to spend a summer's day
text: This park should be part of your summer agenda. Very relaxing and a great opportunity for people watching. Bring a blanket and buy your lunch from the many local vendors around the park.

reviews.title: Hipsters in their natural environment
text: This is a nice park to spend an afternoon in. There are tennis courts, community pool, there is a farmer's market on Tuesdays. Lots of cafes along Queen st. Bring your bike and/or your dog and/or your baby and/or your tattoos and you'll fit right in.

reviews.title: Okay for tennis.
text: Nothing special at all. I have never been here without the smell of mary jane even when i've just played tennis for a short time.

reviews.title: Bring a picnic and explore!
text: This park is beautiful! You will often find it populated with the "hipster" crowd as it is the "entrance" to west queen west where art and culture are thriving!

This park is large so it can be easy to get lost but it has an off leash dog park in a valley in the north side. On the west side of the dog park section is an amazing hill to lay on with a beautiful view of the downtown core.

reviews.title: Big park with an amazing off leash area for your dogs
text: This park has a great community feel. It hosts several fairs through the year and has enough space for a quiet stroll, a coffee or a picnic, or a time with your 4 legged best friend chasing balls in the sunken off leash area.

reviews.title: Take a time-out.
text: I live in Toronto and this is my neighbourhood park. There is nothing particularly unique about the park: public first come first use tennis courts, playground, off-leash dog run area, skating rink (January and February) and lots of room to play or chill in the sun or shade.

You'll see all sorts here, parents and kids, older Chinese folks doing tai chi in the morning, tons of hipsters, students. Everyone uses this park. There is some degree of tolerance for drinking or smoking pot, but less for being overtly drunk or stoned.
There's an ok, small farmers market Tuesday afternoon and festivals big and small throughout the warm months.
There are tons of coffee shops and restaurants in the area for take out. Lots of garbage and recycling bins. If you're drinking alcohol offer your empties to people wandering around with bags.
For tourists, this is a great spot for downtime and chilling, people watching. Public restrooms in Community Centre.
As with any public park, avoid being there alone once dark. It's a safe park and part of the city, but don't get a false sense of security watching the sunset with hipsters and overstay on your own.

reviews.title: Secrets within
text: Although High Park gets most of the accolades, this park will invariably be visited and some will probably like it better.  It is more of a city park, as opposed to High Park's almost wilderness feel, and the summer months will mean that this place is full of people.  Digging a little deeper reveals that there is some history here, specifically Garrison Creek, which lies hidden below, having been long since buried.  The city of Toronto guided walk for Garrison Creek is one of the more interesting ones in the city, and this park forms the backbone of it.

reviews.title: Cherry Blossoms at Peak
text: We stopped by on our way back to the hotel to walk through the short alley of cherry trees blossoming at their peak--a delightful taste of spring on a bit of a rainy day.

reviews.title: Nice park in autumn
text: Went for a walk with a friend with a takeaway coffee and it was nice. No long walks to do, but nice place for sitting on a bench for a chat. Lovely autumn colours and views of the CN tower.

reviews.title: Even on a rainy day, it is attractive
text: Unfortunately when I visited this centrally located Toronto park, it was rainy and overcast.
This did not detract from the wonderful greenery of established trees while on sunnier days the ability to play ball games here must be a huge attraction.
There was an adequate nunber of park benches from which to people watch or relax.
I visited this using my TTC streetcar, bus and subway C$12.00 day pass that was good value.

reviews.title: nice park
text: this is quite large park it covers queen st all the way to dundas st. blocks on end of park. lots of old trees, picnics tables kids pool and lots of green space

reviews.title: Beautiful spot, great for locals and tourists alike!
text: I love relaxing at this park with friends. It's a great spot for a picnic, or to play frisbee/baseball/soccer. It's a large, beautiful space right in the centre of the city. There are lots of restaurants and cafes nearby. Perfect spot for a rest if you're visiting the city.

reviews.title: Great Stroll!
text: Perfect place to soak up the Cafe's people watching!!
Trinity Bellwoods Park is a beautiful park where you can forget the large city & stroll around to your heart's content!

reviews.title: Huge, beautiful park in a really cool part of Toronto
text: Whether you're visiting Toronto or live here, the huge and beautiful Trinity Bellwoods Park and its surrounding cafes and shops is a must.

The park itself has many beautiful trees to sit under, park benches, tennis courts, a children's playground, with climbers and swings, a paddling pool and a nearby Community Centre, with a swimming pool.

Opposite the park, on Queen St West, you'll find a cafe/cake shop called Nadege, where you can sit outside on a nice day and drink some of the best coffee in Toronto and gorge on sumptious cakes. Then you might want to wander round The Paper Place, a store packed with wonderful Japanese papers, fun gift nick-nacks, pens, cards  and everything you'll need if you like to do bookbinding.
Then there's Chippys, the classy fish and chip shop ( although, as someone born and raised in England, I give the fish and chips about a B and think they're over-priced.)
Anyway, in the summer, Trinity Bellwoods Park is hopping. Drummers, yard sales, live music, dancers, people having picnics, or quietly reading in the sun. Come and experience Toronto at its best.

reviews.title: Nice walk
text: Great place to stretch your legs and get out and get some fresh air
Can be some interesting people in the area and here as well
Number of places to grab a bite and have a drink in the area

reviews.title: ice skating during winter
text: They have a place for ice skating, it's really nice. you don't have to pay and everybody can join. also, people take dogs there and the dogs interact, super cute!

reviews.title: Beautiful Park in the Queen West Neighbourhood
text: Trinity Bellwoods is a large urban park located in the trendy and historic Queen West neighbourhood with lots of mature trees, grassy areas for picnicking, tennis courts, and pathways for walking.

It’s a busy place during the summer and there is always lots of activity. I enjoyed sitting under a large shade tree on a hot day and just relaxing and people watching. It was a peaceful place and I also loved walking the winding pathways through the park. I recommend a visit if you’re in the area.

reviews.title: Picnic or Party - A Good Hang
text: This is a mid-sized, often jam-packed park. It's a fun place to hook up with friends, go for a picnic or just walk through and see if anything is happening. The Queen West neighbourhood is saturated with artists so this isn't a particularly quiet park. But it IS fun!

reviews.title: Best park in Toronto
text: I love this park to just chill and watch the world go by. There's activities everywhere, frisbee, softball, soccer etc. Great place to chill

reviews.title: Nice green space
text: The park and its surrounding neighbourhood (Queen Street West) is a lovely area to spend a day in Toronto.

reviews.title: One of my favourite parks in the city!
text: Below it asked me if this place has a coffee shop or restaurant, and while the park does not, there are TONS of options around the park. We came here today to view the cherry blossoms, and so did lots of other people :) This park has lots to do, and is beautifully laid out. A great place for a walk on a sunny day!

reviews.title: Nice park, very crowded in the summer
text: this is a nice park with a good mix of people from young families to people walking their dogs while others play Frisbee, walk, run. It can get very crowded in the summer/warmer months so if you are looking to come for a picnic keep that in mind.

reviews.title: Awesome park in the perfect spot
text: Our friend lives in this area and was excited to show us this cool place. Its great to have a big green space just out of downtown to get away from the city noise. It has large open areas for picnics and sunbathing. Baseball pitches and 8 tennis courts. There is always things going on. Some guys were drumming in the amphitheatre area the Sunday we visited. There are public toilets which can be a rarity in Canada. Even when its busy at weekends its spacious and peaceful. It also has market stalls selling odds and ends as well as art. We got there easily on the streetcar on king street.

reviews.title: Great green space
text: Trinity Bellwoods is flanked by rapidly gentrifying Ossington on the west and Queen St on the east. One of my favourite things here is actually the cherry blossoms in May-June. Great for an urban picnic. Terrific restaurants nearby too.

reviews.title: A Nice Park
text: We decided to visit this park on one of the sunny mornings on our visit to Toronto. It is ideally situated not far from the city. The place is ideal for you to spend hours. You can jog, you can stroll. There are Tennis Courts for you to play . Dog Owners take their Dogs for walk here.You can see scores of people playing various games and sports here. You can spend hours here rejuvenating your self.

reviews.title: Gorgeous in the spring!
text: We visited this park today and it was absolutely beautiful with all of the flowers and trees in full bloom. There's lots of places to sit (benches & grass) and enjoy a cup of coffee, people watch, or bring your dog to play. The entrance to the park is also marked by intricate gates, which are a great background for those Insta pics!!
